displayed_text: Family Member: He had egg McMuffins today, too. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: I had an egg McMuffin, but you know what? I ate it without a muffin. (Laughter) Doctor: I was going to say, maybe you do it without the muffin. I think the hemoglobin A one C is one reflection but it’s not the only reflection, and- Patient: I thought that was the more accurate of the two. Doctor: Yes and no, but you shouldn’t - you should have some stability in your sugar. You know what I mean? Patient: Uh-huh. Uh-huh. Doctor: Three eighty five, no matter where you are in your day, is too high. Patient: Yes. Yeah. Family Member: It will make you feel sick. Doctor: It’ll make you feel sick. Family Member: And tired.

Patient: Hip. Doctor: Okay. Huh, okay, and, huh, any falls? Patient: No. Doctor: And how’s your headaches been? Patient: One side of pain right here, I don’t have any. Doctor: And no trouble swallowing? Patient: No. I don’t have any. Doctor: Still any numbness around your mouth or-? Patient: A little bit when, you know, coughing. Doctor: So. So how often are you taking the morphine? Patient: About two at night. Doctor: A little, nothing during the day?

Patient: I just want to be around a little bit longer, that’s all. Doctor: Well, our hope is that as well. Huh, my sense is, you know, these next drugs we, huh, huh, can get you a little bit more mileage, and you still haven’t had chemotherapy, which could get you some mileage. Huh, there’s an IV radiation drug that can get you a mileage. Most of it’s kicking the can down the street. Huh, we’ve got clinical trials at different points of new drugs, different drugs, combinations of drugs, huh, that we could think about. Huh, yes, so there’s a lot of things out there. It’s a matter of how much you want to go through, the rest of your body, your heart, the other things can get through because the next two drugs, we pick one of them. Huh, one of them is abiraterone, which is probably the cheaper of the two. It’s just gone generic. That doesn’t mean it’s cheap. Huh, but it’s about eleven, twelve thousand dollars a month. Huh, we check with your insurance carrier to see how much they cover. Huh, are you, huh, Medicare, Medicaid, huh, regular insurance, or-? Patient: Right now. Family Member: The next couple of days he’s regular insurance, but he’s going to get Medicare the first of March. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And that will help out. Patient: March first I start Medicare plus a supplement. Doctor: Yeah. Maybe with part D? Family Member: Yes. Patient: D and F, I think. Doctor: That would be great. So again, we may want to ask our pharmacy to look at the medicine next week once you’re on Medicare. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, because again, they will pay eighty percent.

Healthcare Professional: and the report right now so I’m just gonna Doctor: Oh like for July? Healthcare Professional: Yes. So, if you can sign and date, I’m sorry to interrupt you, Doctor: No, no no Healthcare Professional: but I figured if I can get it while… Doctor: J____ is like Speedy Gonzales. She’s like let’s roll, let’s roll. Healthcare Professional: It’s really so I don’t forget it later. Doctor: Okay, we’re having a good discussion. They were afraid I was gonna give them a quiz at the end of it but I think we’re good. Healthcare Professional: Alright, I promise not to, no, I probably shouldn’t promise I won’t interrupt again. Doctor: Of course you won’t. Family Member: So, if it’s bone only after the scans, Doctor: Yeah Family Member: it’s radium for sure?

Family Member: And the scale - is that improving or not or - Patient: Thirty-eight point six or thirty-eight. Family Member: I don’t know Doctor: It was forty-eight in July. Patient: Right. Doctor: And when I saw him on November seventh he had been on the pills for two weeks. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And then so that could be one of the first things that drops the PSA and then we expect with that shot that you received that it’s going to drop it even further. And so that’s what we’re looking for today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so we’re really with our fingers crossed that you know your cancer is shrinking and diving because of what we’ve done, and uh that the issue with that big amount of cancer that is around how your urine gets out of your body—that also will improve, and then we could think about getting your catheter out. Patient: Uh hum. That sounds good. Doctor: This is a copy for us.

Patient: Don’t take it tomorrow? Doctor: Don’t take it tomorrow. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let me see what your testosterone level is and I’m going to put in for a different injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Unfortunately that means it’ll have to be a monthly shot, but you know we may have to do that if your testosterone is not suppressed. Because if the Lupron is not working for you… Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, I need to switch to a different medication. Patient: Right, I understand. Doctor: That’s what I’m talking about. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So that uh

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah, Yeah. Because we can have S____ call you or somebody in our social work team. Do you want to do that? So we get proactive on this? Patient: I’m not ready for that. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. Patient: Um, but I know that that help is there. Doctor: So yeah, of course. Patient: You know, I'm not retiring tomorrow. Doctor: No, we don't want to leave you hanging. Patient: I mean, I don't think I am. Doctor: Right. So you're not planning it? Patient: Yes. Right. Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Okay. So I think, you know, depending on so you'll finish reading the consent, if it's of interest call M___ back and say, okay, their next step would be to bring you in and actually formally review everything and get blood work on that day- Patient: Mhm.

Family Member: It’s between Johannesburg and on the Cape Peninsula area. Because that’s what they were telling us. Ya’ll need to put your feet in the Indian. Doctor: Oh. The Indian Ocean? Patient: Oh, yeah. Doctor: Oh, yeah, that’s right, the Indian Ocean. Family Member: Um hum. Yeah. Doctor: The Indian Ocean comes over to that. That’s wild. Family Member: Right. (Laughter) Patient: Oh, yeah. That was a deep, deep, deep, deep experience. Doctor: Well, I’m glad it all went well for you. Family Member: Yeah. It was nice. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: All right. We’ll get you moving.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now, the computer flips a coin and says whether you’re getting it or not. But you still would be coming in two times a week to get an infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That infusion could be real stuff, real vitamin C. Or it could be sugar. Patient: Okay. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? Huh, so it really is asking a lot of you to give us extra time to sort out whether giving vitamin C makes a difference. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So the theory is vitamin C in high doses may have a, let you have less side effects from the chemotherapy. Huh, at high doses, it may make the chemotherapy work better. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Old data says that sometimes if you take too much vitamin C when you’re getting chemotherapy it could protect the cells, in this case the cancer cells, which we don’t want to protect, and maybe make the chemo work less well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But have less side effects. Okay? So that’s why we have the dummy pill. Okay? Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay, Alright. Family Member: Just for the first few days? Doctor: Yeah, they’ll give you like a set time. Oh, yeah, yeah, yeah, and same thing, you know, when you go to the bathroom. It’s the same thing because he doesn’t want to nail you just because you’re sitting next to him it shouldn’t be but, you know, for the younger people or people who are more immunocompromised who are older they get at risk for stuff and we say why bother. Family Member: They won’t put a port in him will they? Doctor: No, we shouldn’t have to. We shouldn’t have to. Family Member: Even though when they get him they go to the Docetaxal? Doctor: Now, Oh, well, from a chemo standpoint we might have to negotiate that. For sure if you get on the high-dose vitamin C one that is more labor intensive because the chemo is once every three months, not three months, once every three weeks. He got hopeful there for a minute. No, sorry, once every three weeks but the vitamin C is twice a week because it’s at such a high dose. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Well, think about normal stuff you would pop every day you’d almost have to take it multiple times a day to get that dose. This would be the super high one so you’re here like twice a week for like weeks and months. I mean we hope it’s that long because that means it’s working, but yeah, that’s a bit of a slightly draining on that one Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but I have a lot of people who just want their hands on high-dose vitamin C because this is you know, formulated differently than just sort of generic stuff. This is really done with the right, you know, it’s made by a company that’s sort of a spinoff of Hopkins so it’s a very well-regulated product. Um, but, can I tell you that if you’re on placebo you still have to be here? Yeah, because I don’t know who’s getting what. So, the three of us would be fast friends for weeks. Every day it’d be like hello, hello. Just take your name and tape it on an infusion area and you’ll see M____ and S____ all the time. So, that’s one but we’ll work on that. Patient: Okay.

Patient: I don’t know, I…maybe it’s age. Doctor: You’re not that old yet. (laughs) Patient: Oh. (chuckles) Doctor: That’s young, in this day and age. Patient: Yeah. Uh-huh. Doctor: Any other new symptoms? So fatigue is maybe a bit worse? Patient: I feel so; I, I uh I govern that by my ability to you know do things around the house. So whether it’s supporting activities, playing golf I don’t have any energy. And possibly because I’m a little heavier now, too. I’ve gained a few pounds. Doctor: Now are you still trying to be as active as possible, for example, golf or other activities? Or has that been slowing you down? Patient: I’m trying, but I just don’t have the energy. Doctor: Okay, uh any other issues with hot flashes or night sweats? Patient: No, no. Not night sweats, but I do recognize that at times I’m sitting in church and for some reason I just start where other folks are you know are just perfectly calm and cool. Doctor: So during the day just out of the blue? Patient: Yeah, just out of the blue. It last for a few minutes and then stops.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You know, that’s not you and it kind of, you know, we were hoping with a little bit more time away from the Xtandi that that would have been you Patient: Right. Doctor: but that’s not the way you’re declaring yourself so, no, it won’t help. Patient: Okay. That’s no problem. Doctor: Yeah, we just need to move on to something a little bit more powerful. That is powerful in the right setting. You know, kind of like you’re almost like you have the flu and then I come around hey, did you want that flu shot, I’m kind of in the middle of it so no point whereas if this was a few months ago and it’s before flu season then it’s hey, it’s time for the flu shot. Okay, I’ll get it before I’m actually having the flu and the symptoms. Patient: That reminds me of another question. Doctor: Um hmm. Come in. Healthcare Professional: Guess who? Doctor: Hey does he get a copy or is it just us for the…? Healthcare Professional: No, not usually but we can. Doctor: Okay, no then we’re good. Healthcare Professional: Do you want a copy?

Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: Yes, yes. Doctor: Um and it just depends on where you want to see this person. I’m – Do you see the B______ docs? Patient: Yes. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Yep. Are a R____ or T____? Patient: R____. Family Member: R____. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Preferably B______ in uh W____ even. Doctor: So there’s a large nephrology practice at B______. And they’re scattered everywhere. Patient: Right.

Patient: Yeah. It really is sort of out of pocket. Family Member: But he could do it right away? Doctor: He could potentially. I, I, at least I could contact my contact and find out. I also know the group in Heidelberg. We could find out. Uh the groups here, uh I don’t know the Cornell group and the group at UCLA. I don’t know. Those are trials. So they’re going to have eligibility. Patient: Do you think I’d be eligible for them? Doctor: I don’t know. I, I can look into it. Patient: Yeah. I - Doctor: Well, I mean, I don’t know. I can find out from the group at Cornell which sounds like at least would be- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Within striking distance for you from, from the east coast. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: How quickly? If you’re eligible, how quickly you could uh- Patient: Sure. Sure.

Patient: Okay. And that was the same thing with the magnesium. Right? Doctor: Correct Patient: Because you advised no magnesium? Doctor: Well, no. A normal level of magnesium is good. Patient: A normal level Family Member: Like in a multivitamin magnesium? Doctor: Correct. Yes. Family Member: If you could maybe have somebody Google or you Google fluorescence and just see what it’s got that wild Doctor: Okay. Patient: Flor-essence. Doctor: Okay. Flor-essence. Done. Nice to see you. Hello. Hello. Hello. And Good-bye. Do you have enough to eat and drink? Feeling better? Patient: So. Yeah. Oh. I wanted to go to Hospital DR. How do I get to Hospital DR from here? How do I get to DR from here? Can I get a navigator? Doctor: Oh. Yeah a navigator. I couldn’t explain it if my life depended on it, and I’ve been here fourteen years.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.::: strongly disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::strongly agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::strongly agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
